>>618459898
Your comment caught my attention from the last thread. As someone who has a passing interest in Pokémon sexualization this isn't very accurate. Mostly because Pokémon attraction isn't a one way street, smash or pass has shown people are attracted to multiple Pokémon, people who like Gardevoir are very likely to like Lopunny, their smash percent difference is only 2%, and vice versa. The highest rated Pokémon in smash percent were Gardevoir, Lopunny, Delphox, Zoroark, Vaporeon and Ninetales which shows that pokefans have pretty varied taste. Most telling that this isn't the case is the rate of porn growth per month which I've been tracking since September. Lucario and Gardevoir have nearly identical growth followed by Umbreon, Lopunny, Sylveon, and Zoroark who are at 500+. and many others I took track off stand at over 100+. The ones that are in the double digits and below 60 are Hatterene, Meloetta, Tsareena and Lillgant. Clearly human-like apperance isn't that much of a factor in Pokémon attraction, I think it's more fair t say that being the first conventional attractive Pokémon helped it more along with it forming the core of Pokémon attraction with Lucario and Lopunny in gen4.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: No Death Stranding thread?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Common responses:
>You didn't play the game.
Yes I did.
>Filtered.
Good. I'm not a mouth-breathing Kojima drone.
>Walking simulators are a valid game genre. There are others like it.
Death Stranding is a AAA game with massive hype and marketing surrounding it.
Yet it was never honestly marketed as a walking simulator, because then interest in the game would vanish overnight.
I have enjoyed smaller, indie walking simulators because they were marketed exactly as a walking simulator.
My expectations were appropriately managed.
The games were genuinely relaxing, had engaging puzzles/problems, and were suitably short enough for the player to enjoy without getting bored.
Death Stranding is far too long for a walking game, and fails at both being relaxing and having engaging puzzles/problems.
There's just enough time fall and BTs so you can't relax all the time.
But neither are the difficulties actually challenging.
>It's relaxing!
Time fall and BTs are literally there to ruin your scenic walk.
>It's not just walking! Look there's combat!
You concede the point about Death Stranding being relaxing because combat is, broadly speaking, not relaxing.
The amount of combat events are far outweighed by the sheer amount of walking.
Where there is combat and stealth elements, they are ordinary, derivative, and mediocre at best.
A disappointing observation considering Kojima's earlier work with the Metal Gear series.
I'm increasingly convinced that the success of the Metal Gear series isn't attributed to Kojima.
>Well I like it. Why are you raining on my parade?
It's bullshit that Kojima drones are enabling him to shit out this pretentious crap.
I'm writing this to people still on the fence, who haven't played Death Stranding yet, warning them so they don't get fooled into enjoying a AAA, premium shit, walking simulator.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
More common responses:
>Just turn off online features
And ignore one of the game's main selling points? Nice own goal.
>It's not unusual for films to depict ordinary experiences attainable in real life. Why should video games be any different?
Video games are unique because they are interactive, they have gameplay.
It should therefore be every game designer's prerogative to prioritize fun gameplay before anything else, to fully utilize the medium.
Otherwise the game would be no different from a film - which Death Stranding clearly should have been.
>What about sports games? I can play sports in real life.
Sports games actually do provide the unattainable for most people.
The mechanics of the sport is simplified by reducing complex body motion / hand-eye coordination with keyboard/controller interaction.
The player does not experience fatigue, injury, and can be as strong/fast as the game will allow.
On the other hand, walking is a trivial activity.
The weight of the cargo, or lack of (due to exoskeletons), is irrelevant because the player cannot feel it.
>What about Eurotruck simulator?
Death Stranding is still mostly walking.
With Eurotruck, I will still need to purchase a truck, and afford gas.
Walking, on the other hand, is free.
Simulators existed before video games, serving as a way to experiment and train at a substantially lower human and capital cost.
Clearly, they provide experiences that are difficult / not economical in real life.
>Death Stranding allows me to fight BTs.
If only Death Stranding could present these challanges to the player more often, instead of padding out the game with walking 80% of the time.
My argument about the abysmally boring combat still stands, though.
>Death Stranding allows me to walk in a post-apocalyptic environment.
That's just walking with a post-apocalyptic movie. Not gameplay.
>Death Stranding is pure ludo / [Insert celebrity here] is amazing.
Not a substitute for gameplay.

last_replies.com: To be fair, you have to have a very high IQ to understand Death Stranding. The gameplay is extremely subtle, and without a solid grasp of the trigger buttons most of the traversal will go over a typical gamer's head. There's also Kojima's nihilistic outlook, which is deftly woven into his writing - his personal philosophy draws heavily from Hollywood movies, for instance. The fans understand this stuff; they have the intellectual capacity to truly appreciate the depths of these references, to realize that they're not just films - they say something deep about LIFE. As a consequence people who dislike Death Stranding truly ARE idiots- of course they wouldn't appreciate, for instance, the meaning behind Amelie's existential catchphrase "Like Mario and Princess 'Beach'" which itself is a cryptic reference to videogame classic, Super Mario Bros. 2. I'm smirking right now just imagining one of those addlepated simpletons scratching their heads in confusion as Kojima's genius unfolds itself on their television screens. What fools... how I pity them. And yes by the way, I DO have a Norman Reedus tattoo. And no, you cannot see it. It's for the ladies' eyes only- And even they have to demonstrate that they're within 5 IQ points of my own (preferably lower) beforehand.

ELDEN RING? More like ENDLESSLY BORING

Overhyped hack & slash, disguised as an open-world RPG. PS3 level graphics with horrendous performance on high end hardware. Terrible stutters and framedrops. The game itself is boring and bland - the more you play it, the worse it gets. Frustrating hard enemies for no particular reason. Terrible gaming mechanics. There is no way to keep track of what you are doing and what you have done. Morbid, garish art. A non-existent story, with nothing compelling or engaging about it - just a bunch of guess work and theory crafting from NPCs that inhabit reddit & 4chan.

Gameplay itself is a horrendous grind fest, a mindless slog and rewardless git-guddery. The open world is graphically sub-standard (think software from 2013), utterly lifeless and uninteresting with often re-used enemies and terrible dungeon design. The UI is pure horror, game is massively unfun, and terribly ported. It's Dark Souls in an open field with a huge glowing tree in the middle - the "open world" is really just enclosed areas with individual sections, with weird creatures all just waiting until you get within range. There is no AI, just animals and enemies scattered about the landscape - step inside their attack radius, they come at you, step outside it, they stop. Even Skyrim's AI was better, and that game is 11 years old.

Elden Ring screams Japanese nihilism, that's why it's so fundamentally bad. I admire the tech & production values, but the game itself is soulless & empty. It's no coincidence that the only people finding this deeply engaging are manchildren who never had one original thought in their entire lives. Also no coincidence that the toxic community shits on anyone criticizing it instead of playing this garbage. Stay far away.

last_replies.com:
They were certainly going for something completely different with the Greek trilogy. It was a hack and slash / character action / whatever game at its core, story wasn't important, KRATOS IS PISSED, that's all the motivation you really need. Because of how fantastical everything is, you end up with way cooler setpieces because Kratos is capable of absurd superhuman feats of acrobatics
The Norse games are far more grounded and story driven. Kratos typically isn't alone, so there's more dialog and less spectacle. He's still super strong, but he can't abandon his son and he's trying to set a good example.
God of War is one of the best examples of a series adapting to changing tastes and expectations in the industry. Just like how Jak and Daxter devolved into a GTA clone, God of War devolved into a Last of Us clone. That doesn't inherently make it bad, but there's nothing wrong with preferring one over the other.

>>618446820
>the only counterargument to SBMM is "I want to crush new players because I can't handle losing against fairly matched players"

It’s not the only argument. I’m not opposed to SBMM in every game, but for a casual game, it prohibits variety. It is fun to stomp noobs, it is fun to get stomped and have your ego get checked and feel the drive to improve, and it is fun to have an even matchup. If I had to only experience one type of game over and over in a game that I consider casual and don’t take too seriously, it makes the game predictable and boring.

That being said, I understand the main argument for SBMM is to help protect absolute beginners. I wouldn’t want to play against someone who doesn’t know where they Y button is either. So SBMM for the bottom 10-20% of players makes sense, but once you get out of the protected bracket, a range of 30-60% SBMM is ideal for the majority of the population.
